00019 /*! \file
00020  * \brief General Asterisk PBX channel definitions.
00021  * \par See also:
00022  *  \arg \ref Def_Channel
00023  *  \arg \ref channel_drivers

00025 
00026 /*! \page Def_Channel Asterisk Channels
00027    \par What is a Channel?
00028    A phone call through Asterisk consists of an incoming
00029    connection and an outbound connection. Each call comes
00030    in through a channel driver that supports one technology,
00031    like SIP, ZAP, IAX2 etc. 
00032    \par
00033    Each channel driver, technology, has it's own private
00034    channel or dialog structure, that is technology-dependent.
00035    Each private structure is "owned" by a generic Asterisk
00036    channel structure, defined in channel.h and handled by
00037    channel.c .
00038    \par Call scenario
00039    This happens when an incoming call arrives to Asterisk
00040    -# Call arrives on a channel driver interface
00041    -# Channel driver creates a PBX channel and starts a 
00042       pbx thread on the channel
00043    -# The dial plan is executed
00044    -# At this point at least two things can happen:
00045       -# The call is answered by Asterisk and 
00046          Asterisk plays a media stream or reads media
00047       -# The dial plan forces Asterisk to create an outbound 
00048          call somewhere with the dial (see \ref app_dial.c)
00049          application
00050    .
00051 
00052    \par Bridging channels
00053    If Asterisk dials out this happens:
00054    -# Dial creates an outbound PBX channel and asks one of the
00055       channel drivers to create a call
00056    -# When the call is answered, Asterisk bridges the media streams
00057       so the caller on the first channel can speak with the callee
00058       on the second, outbound channel
00059    -# In some cases where we have the same technology on both
00060       channels and compatible codecs, a native bridge is used.
00061       In a native bridge, the channel driver handles forwarding
00062       of incoming audio to the outbound stream internally, without
00063       sending audio frames through the PBX.
00064    -# In SIP, theres an "external native bridge" where Asterisk
00065       redirects the endpoint, so audio flows directly between the
00066       caller's phone and the callee's phone. Signalling stays in
00067       Asterisk in order to be able to provide a proper CDR record
00068       for the call.
00069 
00070    
00071    \par Masquerading channels
00072    In some cases, a channel can masquerade itself into another
00073    channel. This happens frequently in call transfers, where 
00074    a new channel takes over a channel that is already involved
00075    in a call. The new channel sneaks in and takes over the bridge
00076    and the old channel, now a zombie, is hung up.
00077    
00078    \par Reference
00079    \arg channel.c - generic functions
00080    \arg channel.h - declarations of functions, flags and structures
00081    \arg translate.h - Transcoding support functions
00082    \arg \ref channel_drivers - Implemented channel drivers
00083    \arg \ref Def_Frame Asterisk Multimedia Frames
00084    \arg \ref Def_Bridge
00085 
00086 */
00087 /*! \page Def_Bridge Asterisk Channel Bridges
00088 
00089    In Asterisk, there's several media bridges. 
00090 
00091    The Core bridge handles two channels (a "phone call") and bridge
00092    them together.
00093    
00094    The conference bridge (meetme) handles several channels simultaneously
00095    with the support of an external timer (zaptel timer). This is used
00096    not only by the Conference application (meetme) but also by the
00097    page application and the SLA system introduced in 1.4.
00098    The conference bridge does not handle video.
00099 
00100    When two channels of the same type connect, the channel driver
00101    or the media subsystem used by the channel driver (i.e. RTP)
00102    can create a native bridge without sending media through the
00103    core.
00104 
00105    Native briding can be disabled by a number of reasons,
00106    like DTMF being needed by the core or codecs being incompatible
00107    so a transcoding module is needed.
00108 
00109 References:
00110         - ast_channel_early_bridge()
00111         - ast_channel_bridge()
00112    - app_meetme.c
00113    - \ref AstRTPbridge
00114         - ast_rtp_bridge() 
00115    - \ref Def_Channel
00116 */
00117 
00118 /*! \page AstFileDesc File descriptors 
00119    Asterisk File descriptors are connected to each channel (see \ref Def_Channel)
00120    in the \ref ast_channel structure.
00121 */

00205 /*! \brief Structure for all kinds of caller ID identifications.
00206  * \note All string fields here are malloc'ed, so they need to be
00207  * freed when the structure is deleted.
00208  * Also, NULL and "" must be considered equivalent.
00209  */
00210 struct ast_callerid {
00211    char *cid_dnid;      /*!< Malloc'd Dialed Number Identifier */
00212    char *cid_num;    /*!< Malloc'd Caller Number */
00213    char *cid_name;      /*!< Malloc'd Caller Name */
00214    char *cid_ani;    /*!< Malloc'd ANI */
00215    char *cid_rdnis;  /*!< Malloc'd RDNIS */
00216    int cid_pres;     /*!< Callerid presentation/screening */
00217    int cid_ani2;     /*!< Callerid ANI 2 (Info digits) */
00218    int cid_ton;      /*!< Callerid Type of Number */
00219    int cid_tns;      /*!< Callerid Transit Network Select */
00220 };

00222 /*! \brief 
00223    Structure to describe a channel "technology", ie a channel driver 
00224    See for examples:
00225    \arg chan_iax2.c - The Inter-Asterisk exchange protocol
00226    \arg chan_sip.c - The SIP channel driver
00227    \arg chan_zap.c - PSTN connectivity (TDM, PRI, T1/E1, FXO, FXS)
00228 
00229    If you develop your own channel driver, this is where you
00230    tell the PBX at registration of your driver what properties
00231    this driver supports and where different callbacks are 
00232    implemented.
00233 */
00234 struct ast_channel_tech {
00235    const char * const type;
00236    const char * const description;
00237 
00238    int capabilities;    /*!< Bitmap of formats this channel can handle */
00239 
00240    int properties;         /*!< Technology Properties */
00241 
00242    /*! \brief Requester - to set up call data structures (pvt's) */
00243    struct ast_channel *(* const requester)(const char *type, int format, void *data, int *cause);
00244 
00245    int (* const devicestate)(void *data); /*!< Devicestate call back */
00246 
00247    /*! \brief Start sending a literal DTMF digit */
00248    int (* const send_digit_begin)(struct ast_channel *chan, char digit);
00249 
00250    /*! \brief Stop sending a literal DTMF digit */
00251    int (* const send_digit_end)(struct ast_channel *chan, char digit, unsigned int duration);
00252 
00253    /*! \brief Call a given phone number (address, etc), but don't
00254       take longer than timeout seconds to do so.  */
00255    int (* const call)(struct ast_channel *chan, char *addr, int timeout);
00256 
00257    /*! \brief Hangup (and possibly destroy) the channel */
00258    int (* const hangup)(struct ast_channel *chan);
00259 
00260    /*! \brief Answer the channel */
00261    int (* const answer)(struct ast_channel *chan);
00262 
00263    /*! \brief Read a frame, in standard format (see frame.h) */
00264    struct ast_frame * (* const read)(struct ast_channel *chan);
00265 
00266    /*! \brief Write a frame, in standard format (see frame.h) */
00267    int (* const write)(struct ast_channel *chan, struct ast_frame *frame);
00268 
00269    /*! \brief Display or transmit text */
00270    int (* const send_text)(struct ast_channel *chan, const char *text);
00271 
00272    /*! \brief Display or send an image */
00273    int (* const send_image)(struct ast_channel *chan, struct ast_frame *frame);
00274 
00275    /*! \brief Send HTML data */
00276    int (* const send_html)(struct ast_channel *chan, int subclass, const char *data, int len);
00277 
00278    /*! \brief Handle an exception, reading a frame */
00279    struct ast_frame * (* const exception)(struct ast_channel *chan);
00280 
00281    /*! \brief Bridge two channels of the same type together */
00282    enum ast_bridge_result (* const bridge)(struct ast_channel *c0, struct ast_channel *c1, int flags,
00283                   struct ast_frame **fo, struct ast_channel **rc, int timeoutms);
00284

00287 
00288    /*! \brief Indicate a particular condition (e.g. AST_CONTROL_BUSY or AST_CONTROL_RINGING or AST_CONTROL_CONGESTION */
00289    int (* const indicate)(struct ast_channel *c, int condition, const void *data, size_t datalen);
00290 
00291    /*! \brief Fix up a channel:  If a channel is consumed, this is called.  Basically update any ->owner links */
00292    int (* const fixup)(struct ast_channel *oldchan, struct ast_channel *newchan);
00293 
00294    /*! \brief Set a given option */
00295    int (* const setoption)(struct ast_channel *chan, int option, void *data, int datalen);
00296 
00297    /*! \brief Query a given option */
00298    int (* const queryoption)(struct ast_channel *chan, int option, void *data, int *datalen);
00299 
00300    /*! \brief Blind transfer other side (see app_transfer.c and ast_transfer() */

00302 
00303    /*! \brief Write a frame, in standard format */
00304    int (* const write_video)(struct ast_channel *chan, struct ast_frame *frame);
00305 
00306    /*! \brief Write a text frame, in standard format */
00307    int (* const write_text)(struct ast_channel *chan, struct ast_frame *frame);
00308 
00309    /*! \brief Find bridged channel */
00310    struct ast_channel *(* const bridged_channel)(struct ast_channel *chan, struct ast_channel *bridge);
00311 
00312    /*! \brief Provide additional read items for CHANNEL() dialplan function */

00314 
00315    /*! \brief Provide additional write items for CHANNEL() dialplan function */

00317 };

00322 /*!
00323  * The high bit of the frame count is used as a debug marker, so
00324  * increments of the counters must be done with care.
00325  * Please use c->fin = FRAMECOUNT_INC(c->fin) and the same for c->fout.
00326  */
00327 #define  DEBUGCHAN_FLAG  0x80000000
00328 
00329 /* XXX not ideal to evaluate x twice... */
00330 #define  FRAMECOUNT_INC(x) ( ((x) & DEBUGCHAN_FLAG) | (((x)+1) & ~DEBUGCHAN_FLAG) )
00331 
00332 /*!
00333  * The current value of the debug flags is stored in the two
00334  * variables global_fin and global_fout (declared in main/channel.c)
00335  */
00336 extern unsigned long global_fin, global_fout;

00338 enum ast_channel_adsicpe {
00339    AST_ADSI_UNKNOWN,
00340    AST_ADSI_AVAILABLE,
00341    AST_ADSI_UNAVAILABLE,
00342    AST_ADSI_OFFHOOKONLY,
00343 };
00344 
00345 /*! 
00346  * \brief ast_channel states
00347  *
00348  * \note Bits 0-15 of state are reserved for the state (up/down) of the line
00349  *       Bits 16-32 of state are reserved for flags
00350  */
00351 enum ast_channel_state {
00352    /*! Channel is down and available */
00353    AST_STATE_DOWN,
00354    /*! Channel is down, but reserved */
00355    AST_STATE_RESERVED,
00356    /*! Channel is off hook */
00357    AST_STATE_OFFHOOK,
00358    /*! Digits (or equivalent) have been dialed */
00359    AST_STATE_DIALING,
00360    /*! Line is ringing */
00361    AST_STATE_RING,
00362    /*! Remote end is ringing */
00363    AST_STATE_RINGING,
00364    /*! Line is up */
00365    AST_STATE_UP,
00366    /*! Line is busy */
00367    AST_STATE_BUSY,
00368    /*! Digits (or equivalent) have been dialed while offhook */
00369    AST_STATE_DIALING_OFFHOOK,
00370    /*! Channel has detected an incoming call and is waiting for ring */
00371    AST_STATE_PRERING,
00372 
00373    /*! Do not transmit voice data */
00374    AST_STATE_MUTE = (1 << 16),
00375 };
00376 
00377 /*! \brief Main Channel structure associated with a channel. 
00378  * This is the side of it mostly used by the pbx and call management.
00379  *
00380  * \note XXX It is important to remember to increment .cleancount each time
00381  *       this structure is changed. XXX
00382  */
00383 struct ast_channel {
00384    /*! \brief Technology (point to channel driver) */
00385    const struct ast_channel_tech *tech;
00386 
00387    /*! \brief Private data used by the technology driver */
00388    void *tech_pvt;
00389 
00390    AST_DECLARE_STRING_FIELDS(
00391       AST_STRING_FIELD(name);       /*!< ASCII unique channel name */
00392       AST_STRING_FIELD(language);      /*!< Language requested for voice prompts */
00393       AST_STRING_FIELD(musicclass);    /*!< Default music class */
00394       AST_STRING_FIELD(accountcode);      /*!< Account code for billing */
00395       AST_STRING_FIELD(call_forward);     /*!< Where to forward to if asked to dial on this interface */
00396       AST_STRING_FIELD(uniqueid);      /*!< Unique Channel Identifier */
00397    );
00398    
00399    /*! \brief File descriptor for channel -- Drivers will poll on these file descriptors, so at least one must be non -1.  See \ref AstFileDesc */
00400    int fds[AST_MAX_FDS];   
00401 
00402    void *music_state;            /*!< Music State*/
00403    void *generatordata;          /*!< Current generator data if there is any */
00404    struct ast_generator *generator;    /*!< Current active data generator */
00405 
00406    /*! \brief Who are we bridged to, if we're bridged. Who is proxying for us,
00407      if we are proxied (i.e. chan_agent).
00408      Do not access directly, use ast_bridged_channel(chan) */
00409    struct ast_channel *_bridge;
00410    struct ast_channel *masq;        /*!< Channel that will masquerade as us */
00411    struct ast_channel *masqr;       /*!< Who we are masquerading as */
00412    int cdrflags;              /*!< Call Detail Record Flags */
00413 
00414    int _softhangup;           /*!< Whether or not we have been hung up...  Do not set this value
00415                            directly, use ast_softhangup() */
00416    time_t   whentohangup;           /*!< Non-zero, set to actual time when channel is to be hung up */
00417    pthread_t blocker;            /*!< If anyone is blocking, this is them */
00418    ast_mutex_t lock;          /*!< Lock, can be used to lock a channel for some operations - see ast_channel_lock() */
00419    const char *blockproc;           /*!< Procedure causing blocking */
00420 
00421    const char *appl;          /*!< Current application */
00422    const char *data;          /*!< Data passed to current application */
00423    int fdno;               /*!< Which fd had an event detected on */
00424    struct sched_context *sched;        /*!< Schedule context */
00425    int streamid;              /*!< For streaming playback, the schedule ID */
00426    struct ast_filestream *stream;         /*!< Stream itself. */
00427    int vstreamid;             /*!< For streaming video playback, the schedule ID */
00428    struct ast_filestream *vstream;        /*!< Video Stream itself. */
00429    int oldwriteformat;           /*!< Original writer format */
00430    
00431    int timingfd;              /*!< Timing fd */
00432    int (*timingfunc)(void *data);
00433    void *timingdata;
00434 
00435    enum ast_channel_state _state;         /*!< State of line -- Don't write directly, use ast_setstate() */
00436    int rings;              /*!< Number of rings so far */
00437    struct ast_callerid cid;         /*!< Caller ID, name, presentation etc */
00438    char dtmfq[AST_MAX_EXTENSION];         /*!< Any/all queued DTMF characters */
00439    struct ast_frame dtmff;          /*!< DTMF frame */
00440 
00441    char context[AST_MAX_CONTEXT];         /*!< Dialplan: Current extension context */
00442    char exten[AST_MAX_EXTENSION];         /*!< Dialplan: Current extension number */
00443    int priority;              /*!< Dialplan: Current extension priority */
00444    char macrocontext[AST_MAX_CONTEXT];    /*!< Macro: Current non-macro context. See app_macro.c */
00445    char macroexten[AST_MAX_EXTENSION];    /*!< Macro: Current non-macro extension. See app_macro.c */
00446    int macropriority;            /*!< Macro: Current non-macro priority. See app_macro.c */
00447    char dialcontext[AST_MAX_CONTEXT];              /*!< Dial: Extension context that we were called from */
00448 
00449    struct ast_pbx *pbx;          /*!< PBX private structure for this channel */
00450    int amaflags;              /*!< Set BEFORE PBX is started to determine AMA flags */
00451    struct ast_cdr *cdr;          /*!< Call Detail Record */
00452    enum ast_channel_adsicpe adsicpe;      /*!< Whether or not ADSI is detected on CPE */
00453 
00454    struct ind_tone_zone *zone;         /*!< Tone zone as set in indications.conf or
00455                         in the CHANNEL dialplan function */
00456 
00457    struct ast_channel_monitor *monitor;      /*!< Channel monitoring */
00458 
00459    unsigned long insmpl;            /*!< Track the read/written samples for monitor use */
00460    unsigned long outsmpl;           /*!< Track the read/written samples for monitor use */
00461 
00462    unsigned int fin;          /*!< Frames in counters. The high bit is a debug mask, so
00463                       * the counter is only in the remaining bits */
00464    unsigned int fout;            /*!< Frames out counters. The high bit is a debug mask, so
00465                       * the counter is only in the remaining bits */
00466    int hangupcause;           /*!< Why is the channel hanged up. See causes.h */
00467    struct varshead varshead;        /*!< A linked list for channel variables 
00468                         (see \ref AstChanVar ) */
00469    ast_group_t callgroup;           /*!< Call group for call pickups */
00470    ast_group_t pickupgroup;         /*!< Pickup group - which calls groups can be picked up? */
00471    unsigned int flags;           /*!< channel flags of AST_FLAG_ type */
00472    unsigned short transfercapability;     /*!< ISDN Transfer Capbility - AST_FLAG_DIGITAL is not enough */
00473    AST_LIST_HEAD_NOLOCK(, ast_frame) readq;
00474    int alertpipe[2];
00475 
00476    int nativeformats;            /*!< Kinds of data this channel can natively handle */
00477    int readformat;               /*!< Requested read format */
00478    int writeformat;           /*!< Requested write format */
00479    struct ast_trans_pvt *writetrans;      /*!< Write translation path */
00480    struct ast_trans_pvt *readtrans;    /*!< Read translation path */
00481    int rawreadformat;            /*!< Raw read format */
00482    int rawwriteformat;           /*!< Raw write format */
00483 
00484    struct ast_channel_spy_list *spies;    /*!< Chan Spy stuff */
00485    struct ast_channel_whisper_buffer *whisper;  /*!< Whisper Paging buffer */
00486    AST_LIST_ENTRY(ast_channel) chan_list;    /*!< For easy linking */
00487    
00488    struct ast_jb jb;          /*!< The jitterbuffer state  */
00489 
00490    char emulate_dtmf_digit;         /*!< Digit being emulated */
00491    unsigned int emulate_dtmf_duration; /*!< Number of ms left to emulate DTMF for */
00492    struct timeval dtmf_tv;       /*!< The time that an in process digit began, or the last digit ended */
00493 
00494    /*! \brief Data stores on the channel */
00495    AST_LIST_HEAD_NOLOCK(datastores, ast_datastore) datastores;
00496 };

00498 /*! \brief ast_channel_tech Properties */
00499 enum {
00500    /*! \brief Channels have this property if they can accept input with jitter; 
00501     *         i.e. most VoIP channels */
00502    AST_CHAN_TP_WANTSJITTER = (1 << 0),
00503    /*! \brief Channels have this property if they can create jitter; 
00504     *         i.e. most VoIP channels */
00505    AST_CHAN_TP_CREATESJITTER = (1 << 1),
00506 };
00507 
00508 /*! \brief ast_channel flags */
00509 enum {
00510    /*! Queue incoming dtmf, to be released when this flag is turned off */
00511    AST_FLAG_DEFER_DTMF =    (1 << 1),
00512    /*! write should be interrupt generator */
00513    AST_FLAG_WRITE_INT =     (1 << 2),
00514    /*! a thread is blocking on this channel */
00515    AST_FLAG_BLOCKING =      (1 << 3),
00516    /*! This is a zombie channel */
00517    AST_FLAG_ZOMBIE =        (1 << 4),
00518    /*! There is an exception pending */
00519    AST_FLAG_EXCEPTION =     (1 << 5),
00520    /*! Listening to moh XXX anthm promises me this will disappear XXX */
00521    AST_FLAG_MOH =           (1 << 6),
00522    /*! This channel is spying on another channel */
00523    AST_FLAG_SPYING =        (1 << 7),
00524    /*! This channel is in a native bridge */
00525    AST_FLAG_NBRIDGE =       (1 << 8),
00526    /*! the channel is in an auto-incrementing dialplan processor,
00527     *  so when ->priority is set, it will get incremented before
00528     *  finding the next priority to run */
00529    AST_FLAG_IN_AUTOLOOP =   (1 << 9),
00530    /*! This is an outgoing call */
00531    AST_FLAG_OUTGOING =      (1 << 10),
00532    /*! This channel is being whispered on */
00533    AST_FLAG_WHISPER =       (1 << 11),
00534    /*! A DTMF_BEGIN frame has been read from this channel, but not yet an END */
00535    AST_FLAG_IN_DTMF =       (1 << 12),
00536    /*! A DTMF_END was received when not IN_DTMF, so the length of the digit is 
00537     *  currently being emulated */
00538    AST_FLAG_EMULATE_DTMF =  (1 << 13),
00539    /*! This is set to tell the channel not to generate DTMF begin frames, and
00540     *  to instead only generate END frames. */
00541    AST_FLAG_END_DTMF_ONLY = (1 << 14),
00542 };
00543 
00544 /*! \brief ast_bridge_config flags */
00545 enum {
00546    AST_FEATURE_PLAY_WARNING = (1 << 0),
00547    AST_FEATURE_REDIRECT =     (1 << 1),
00548    AST_FEATURE_DISCONNECT =   (1 << 2),
00549    AST_FEATURE_ATXFER =       (1 << 3),
00550    AST_FEATURE_AUTOMON =      (1 << 4),
00551    AST_FEATURE_PARKCALL =     (1 << 5),
00552 };
00553 
00554 /*! \brief bridge configuration */
00555 struct ast_bridge_config {
00556    struct ast_flags features_caller;
00557    struct ast_flags features_callee;
00558    struct timeval start_time;
00559    long feature_timer;
00560    long timelimit;
00561    long play_warning;
00562    long warning_freq;
00563    const char *warning_sound;
00564    const char *end_sound;
00565    const char *start_sound;
00566    int firstpass;
00567    unsigned int flags;
00568 };
00569 
00570 struct chanmon;

00578    const char *account;
00579    struct ast_variable *vars;

00581 };
00582 
00583 enum {
00584    AST_CDR_TRANSFER =   (1 << 0),
00585    AST_CDR_FORWARD =    (1 << 1),
00586    AST_CDR_CALLWAIT =   (1 << 2),
00587    AST_CDR_CONFERENCE = (1 << 3),
00588 };
00589 
00590 enum {
00591    /*! Soft hangup by device */
00592    AST_SOFTHANGUP_DEV =       (1 << 0),
00593    /*! Soft hangup for async goto */
00594    AST_SOFTHANGUP_ASYNCGOTO = (1 << 1),
00595    AST_SOFTHANGUP_SHUTDOWN =  (1 << 2),
00596    AST_SOFTHANGUP_TIMEOUT =   (1 << 3),
00597    AST_SOFTHANGUP_APPUNLOAD = (1 << 4),
00598    AST_SOFTHANGUP_EXPLICIT =  (1 << 5),
00599    AST_SOFTHANGUP_UNBRIDGE =  (1 << 6),
00600 };

00638 struct ast_channel *ast_channel_alloc(int needqueue, int state, const char *cid_num, const char *cid_name, const char *acctcode, const char *exten, const char *context, const int amaflag, const char *name_fmt, ...);

00640 /*! \brief Queue an outgoing frame */
00641 int ast_queue_frame(struct ast_channel *chan, struct ast_frame *f);

00645 
00646 /*!
00647   \brief Queue a control frame with payload
00648   \param chan channel to queue frame onto
00649   \param control type of control frame
00650   \return zero on success, non-zero on failure
00651 */
00652 int ast_queue_control(struct ast_channel *chan, enum ast_control_frame_type control);
00653 
00654 /*!
00655   \brief Queue a control frame with payload
00656   \param chan channel to queue frame onto
00657   \param control type of control frame
00658   \param data pointer to payload data to be included in frame
00659   \param datalen number of bytes of payload data
00660   \return zero on success, non-zero on failure
00661 
00662   The supplied payload data is copied into the frame, so the caller's copy
00663   is not modified nor freed, and the resulting frame will retain a copy of
00664   the data even if the caller frees their local copy.
00665 
00666   \note This method should be treated as a 'network transport'; in other
00667   words, your frames may be transferred across an IAX2 channel to another
00668   system, which may be a different endianness than yours. Because of this,
00669   you should ensure that either your frames will never be expected to work
00670   across systems, or that you always put your payload data into 'network byte
00671   order' before calling this function.
00672 */
00673 int ast_queue_control_data(struct ast_channel *chan, enum ast_control_frame_type control,
00674             const void *data, size_t datalen);
00675

00677 void ast_change_name(struct ast_channel *chan, char *newname);

00682 /*! \brief Requests a channel 
00683  * \param type type of channel to request
00684  * \param format requested channel format (codec)
00685  * \param data data to pass to the channel requester
00686  * \param status status
00687  * Request a channel of a given type, with data as optional information used 
00688  * by the low level module
00689  * \return Returns an ast_channel on success, NULL on failure.
00690  */
00691 struct ast_channel *ast_request(const char *type, int format, void *data, int *status);
00692 
00693 /*!
00694  * \brief Request a channel of a given type, with data as optional information used 
00695  * by the low level module and attempt to place a call on it
00696  * \param type type of channel to request
00697  * \param format requested channel format
00698  * \param data data to pass to the channel requester
00699  * \param timeout maximum amount of time to wait for an answer
00700  * \param reason why unsuccessful (if unsuccessful)
00701  * \param cidnum Caller-ID Number
00702  * \param cidname Caller-ID Name
00703  * \return Returns an ast_channel on success or no answer, NULL on failure.  Check the value of chan->_state
00704  * to know if the call was answered or not.
00705  */
00706 struct ast_channel *ast_request_and_dial(const char *type, int format, void *data, int timeout, int *reason, const char *cidnum, const char *cidname);

00729 /*! \brief Hang up a channel  
00730  * \note This function performs a hard hangup on a channel.  Unlike the soft-hangup, this function
00731  * performs all stream stopping, etc, on the channel that needs to end.
00732  * chan is no longer valid after this call.
00733  * \param chan channel to hang up
00734  * \return Returns 0 on success, -1 on failure.
00735  */
00736 int ast_hangup(struct ast_channel *chan);
00737 
00738 /*! \brief Softly hangup up a channel 
00739  * \param chan channel to be soft-hung-up
00740  * Call the protocol layer, but don't destroy the channel structure (use this if you are trying to
00741  * safely hangup a channel managed by another thread.
00742  * \param cause   Ast hangupcause for hangup
00743  * \return Returns 0 regardless
00744  */
00745 int ast_softhangup(struct ast_channel *chan, int cause);
00746 
00747 /*! \brief Softly hangup up a channel (no channel lock) 
00748  * \param chan channel to be soft-hung-up
00749  * \param cause   Ast hangupcause for hangup (see cause.h) */
00750 int ast_softhangup_nolock(struct ast_channel *chan, int cause);
00751 
00752 /*! \brief Check to see if a channel is needing hang up 
00753  * \param chan channel on which to check for hang up
00754  * This function determines if the channel is being requested to be hung up.
00755  * \return Returns 0 if not, or 1 if hang up is requested (including time-out).
00756  */
00757 int ast_check_hangup(struct ast_channel *chan);
00758 
00759 /*! \brief Compare a offset with the settings of when to hang a channel up 
00760  * \param chan channel on which to check for hang up
00761  * \param offset offset in seconds from current time
00762  * \return 1, 0, or -1
00763  * This function compares a offset from current time with the absolute time 
00764  * out on a channel (when to hang up). If the absolute time out on a channel
00765  * is earlier than current time plus the offset, it returns 1, if the two
00766  * time values are equal, it return 0, otherwise, it return -1.
00767  */
00768 int ast_channel_cmpwhentohangup(struct ast_channel *chan, time_t offset);
00769 
00770 /*! \brief Set when to hang a channel up 
00771  * \param chan channel on which to check for hang up
00772  * \param offset offset in seconds from current time of when to hang up
00773  * This function sets the absolute time out on a channel (when to hang up).
00774  */
00775 void ast_channel_setwhentohangup(struct ast_channel *chan, time_t offset);
00776 
00777 /*! \brief Answer a channel
00778  * \param chan channel to answer
00779  * This function answers a channel and handles all necessary call
00780  * setup functions.
00781  * \return Returns 0 on success, non-zero on failure
00782  */
00783 int ast_answer(struct ast_channel *chan);
00784 int __ast_answer(struct ast_channel *chan, unsigned int delay);
00785 
00786 /*! \brief Make a call 
00787  * \param chan which channel to make the call on
00788  * \param addr destination of the call
00789  * \param timeout time to wait on for connect
00790  * Place a call, take no longer than timeout ms. 
00791    \return Returns -1 on failure, 0 on not enough time 
00792    (does not automatically stop ringing), and  
00793    the number of seconds the connect took otherwise.
00794    */
00795 int ast_call(struct ast_channel *chan, char *addr, int timeout);

00817 /*! \brief Wait for input on a channel

00819  * \param ms length of time to wait on the channel

00823 
00824 /*! \brief Wait for a specified amount of time, looking for hangups 
00825  * \param chan channel to wait for
00826  * \param ms length of time in milliseconds to sleep
00827  * Waits for a specified amount of time, servicing the channel as required.
00828  * \return returns -1 on hangup, otherwise 0.
00829  */
00830 int ast_safe_sleep(struct ast_channel *chan, int ms);
00831 
00832 /*! \brief Wait for a specified amount of time, looking for hangups and a condition argument

00834  * \param ms length of time in milliseconds to sleep

00836  * \param data argument to be passed to the condition test function
00837  * \return returns -1 on hangup, otherwise 0.
00838  * Waits for a specified amount of time, servicing the channel as required. If cond
00839  * returns 0, this function returns.
00840  */
00841 int ast_safe_sleep_conditional(struct ast_channel *chan, int ms, int (*cond)(void*), void *data );

00843 /*! \brief Waits for activity on a group of channels 
00844  * \param chan an array of pointers to channels
00845  * \param n number of channels that are to be waited upon
00846  * \param fds an array of fds to wait upon
00847  * \param nfds the number of fds to wait upon
00848  * \param exception exception flag
00849  * \param outfd fd that had activity on it
00850  * \param ms how long the wait was
00851  * Big momma function here.  Wait for activity on any of the n channels, or any of the nfds
00852    file descriptors.
00853    \return Returns the channel with activity, or NULL on error or if an FD
00854    came first.  If the FD came first, it will be returned in outfd, otherwise, outfd
00855    will be -1 */
00856 struct ast_channel *ast_waitfor_nandfds(struct ast_channel **chan, int n, int *fds, int nfds, int *exception, int *outfd, int *ms);
00857 
00858 /*! \brief Waits for input on a group of channels
00859    Wait for input on an array of channels for a given # of milliseconds. 
00860    \return Return channel with activity, or NULL if none has activity.  
00861    \param chan an array of pointers to channels
00862    \param n number of channels that are to be waited upon
00863    \param ms time "ms" is modified in-place, if applicable */
00864 struct ast_channel *ast_waitfor_n(struct ast_channel **chan, int n, int *ms);
00865

01004 /*! ! \brief Waits for a digit
01005  * \param c channel to wait for a digit on
01006  * \param ms how many milliseconds to wait
01007  * \return Returns <0 on error, 0 on no entry, and the digit on success. */
01008 int ast_waitfordigit(struct ast_channel *c, int ms);
01009 
01010 /*! \brief Wait for a digit
01011  Same as ast_waitfordigit() with audio fd for outputting read audio and ctrlfd to monitor for reading. 
01012  * \param c channel to wait for a digit on
01013  * \param ms how many milliseconds to wait
01014  * \param audiofd audio file descriptor to write to if audio frames are received
01015  * \param ctrlfd control file descriptor to monitor for reading
01016  * \return Returns 1 if ctrlfd becomes available */
01017 int ast_waitfordigit_full(struct ast_channel *c, int ms, int audiofd, int ctrlfd);
01018 
01019 /*! Reads multiple digits 
01020  * \param c channel to read from
01021  * \param s string to read in to.  Must be at least the size of your length
01022  * \param len how many digits to read (maximum)
01023  * \param timeout how long to timeout between digits
01024  * \param rtimeout timeout to wait on the first digit
01025  * \param enders digits to end the string
01026  * Read in a digit string "s", max length "len", maximum timeout between 
01027    digits "timeout" (-1 for none), terminated by anything in "enders".  Give them rtimeout
01028    for the first digit.  Returns 0 on normal return, or 1 on a timeout.  In the case of
01029    a timeout, any digits that were read before the timeout will still be available in s.  
01030    RETURNS 2 in full version when ctrlfd is available, NOT 1*/
01031 int ast_readstring(struct ast_channel *c, char *s, int len, int timeout, int rtimeout, char *enders);
01032 int ast_readstring_full(struct ast_channel *c, char *s, int len, int timeout, int rtimeout, char *enders, int audiofd, int ctrlfd);
01033 
01034 /*! \brief Report DTMF on channel 0 */
01035 #define AST_BRIDGE_DTMF_CHANNEL_0      (1 << 0)    
01036 /*! \brief Report DTMF on channel 1 */
01037 #define AST_BRIDGE_DTMF_CHANNEL_1      (1 << 1)    
01038 /*! \brief Return all voice frames on channel 0 */
01039 #define AST_BRIDGE_REC_CHANNEL_0    (1 << 2)    
01040 /*! \brief Return all voice frames on channel 1 */
01041 #define AST_BRIDGE_REC_CHANNEL_1    (1 << 3)    
01042 /*! \brief Ignore all signal frames except NULL */
01043 #define AST_BRIDGE_IGNORE_SIGS         (1 << 4)    
01044 
01045 
01046 /*! \brief Makes two channel formats compatible 
01047  * \param c0 first channel to make compatible
01048  * \param c1 other channel to make compatible
01049  * Set two channels to compatible formats -- call before ast_channel_bridge in general .  
01050  * \return Returns 0 on success and -1 if it could not be done */
01051 int ast_channel_make_compatible(struct ast_channel *c0, struct ast_channel *c1);
01052 
01053 /*! Bridge two channels together (early)
01054  * \param c0 first channel to bridge
01055  * \param c1 second channel to bridge
01056  * Bridge two channels (c0 and c1) together early. This implies either side may not be answered yet.
01057  * \return Returns 0 on success and -1 if it could not be done */
01058 int ast_channel_early_bridge(struct ast_channel *c0, struct ast_channel *c1);
01059 
01060 /*! Bridge two channels together 
01061  * \param c0 first channel to bridge
01062  * \param c1 second channel to bridge
01063  * \param config config for the channels
01064  * \param fo destination frame(?)
01065  * \param rc destination channel(?)
01066  * Bridge two channels (c0 and c1) together.  If an important frame occurs, we return that frame in
01067    *rf (remember, it could be NULL) and which channel (0 or 1) in rc */
01068 /* int ast_channel_bridge(struct ast_channel *c0, struct ast_channel *c1, int flags, struct ast_frame **fo, struct ast_channel **rc); */
01069 int ast_channel_bridge(struct ast_channel *c0,struct ast_channel *c1,struct ast_bridge_config *config, struct ast_frame **fo, struct ast_channel **rc);
01070 
01071 /*! \brief Weird function made for call transfers
01072  * \param original channel to make a copy of
01073  * \param clone copy of the original channel
01074  * This is a very strange and freaky function used primarily for transfer.  Suppose that
01075    "original" and "clone" are two channels in random situations.  This function takes
01076    the guts out of "clone" and puts them into the "original" channel, then alerts the
01077    channel driver of the change, asking it to fixup any private information (like the
01078    p->owner pointer) that is affected by the change.  The physical layer of the original
01079    channel is hung up.  */
01080 int ast_channel_masquerade(struct ast_channel *original, struct ast_channel *clone);

01302 /*! \brief if fd is a valid descriptor, set *pfd with the descriptor
01303  * \return Return 1 (not -1!) if added, 0 otherwise (so we can add the
01304  * return value to the index into the array)
01305  */
01306 static inline int ast_add_fd(struct pollfd *pfd, int fd)
01307 {
01308    pfd->fd = fd;
01309    pfd->events = POLLIN | POLLPRI;
01310    return fd >= 0;
01311 }
01312 
01313 /*! \brief Helper function for migrating select to poll */
01314 static inline int ast_fdisset(struct pollfd *pfds, int fd, int max, int *start)
01315 {
01316    int x;
01317    int dummy=0;
01318 
01319    if (fd < 0)
01320       return 0;
01321    if (!start)
01322       start = &dummy;
01323    for (x = *start; x<max; x++)
01324       if (pfds[x].fd == fd) {
01325          if (x == *start)
01326             (*start)++;
01327          return pfds[x].revents;
01328       }
01329    return 0;
01330 }
01331 
01332 #ifdef SOLARIS
01333 static inline void timersub(struct timeval *tvend, struct timeval *tvstart, struct timeval *tvdiff)
01334 {
01335    tvdiff->tv_sec = tvend->tv_sec - tvstart->tv_sec;
01336    tvdiff->tv_usec = tvend->tv_usec - tvstart->tv_usec;
01337    if (tvdiff->tv_usec < 0) {
01338       tvdiff->tv_sec --;
01339       tvdiff->tv_usec += 1000000;
01340    }
01341 
01342 }
01343 #endif
01344 
01345 /*! \brief Waits for activity on a group of channels 
01346  * \param nfds the maximum number of file descriptors in the sets
01347  * \param rfds file descriptors to check for read availability
01348  * \param wfds file descriptors to check for write availability
01349  * \param efds file descriptors to check for exceptions (OOB data)
01350  * \param tvp timeout while waiting for events
01351  * This is the same as a standard select(), except it guarantees the
01352  * behaviour where the passed struct timeval is updated with how much
01353  * time was not slept while waiting for the specified events
01354  */
01355 static inline int ast_select(int nfds, fd_set *rfds, fd_set *wfds, fd_set *efds, struct timeval *tvp)
01356 {
01357 #ifdef __linux__
01358    return select(nfds, rfds, wfds, efds, tvp);
01359 #else
01360    if (tvp) {
01361       struct timeval tv, tvstart, tvend, tvlen;
01362       int res;
01363 
01364       tv = *tvp;
01365       gettimeofday(&tvstart, NULL);
01366       res = select(nfds, rfds, wfds, efds, tvp);
01367       gettimeofday(&tvend, NULL);
01368       timersub(&tvend, &tvstart, &tvlen);
01369       timersub(&tv, &tvlen, tvp);
01370       if (tvp->tv_sec < 0 || (tvp->tv_sec == 0 && tvp->tv_usec < 0)) {
01371          tvp->tv_sec = 0;
01372          tvp->tv_usec = 0;
01373       }
01374       return res;
01375    }
01376    else
01377       return select(nfds, rfds, wfds, efds, NULL);
01378 #endif
01379 }
01380 
01381 #ifdef DO_CRASH
01382 #define CRASH do { fprintf(stderr, "!! Forcing immediate crash a-la abort !!\n"); *((int *)0) = 0; } while(0)
01383 #else
01384 #define CRASH do { } while(0)
01385 #endif
01386 
01387 #define CHECK_BLOCKING(c) do {    \
01388    if (ast_test_flag(c, AST_FLAG_BLOCKING)) {\
01389       if (option_debug) \
01390          ast_log(LOG_DEBUG, "Thread %ld Blocking '%s', already blocked by thread %ld in procedure %s\n", (long) pthread_self(), (c)->name, (long) (c)->blocker, (c)->blockproc); \
01391       CRASH; \
01392    } else { \
01393       (c)->blocker = pthread_self(); \
01394       (c)->blockproc = __PRETTY_FUNCTION__; \
01395       ast_set_flag(c, AST_FLAG_BLOCKING); \
01396    } } while (0)
